newsitem.title: PORTUGAL: Portugal plans over $1 bln rail investment.
newsitem.headline: Portugal plans over $1 bln rail investment.

text.p: The Portuguese government plans to invest a record 200 billion escudos ($1.3 billion) in railway projects in 1997, Planning Minister Joao Cravinho said on Monday.
"Railway infrastructure will benefit from a record investment of 200 billion escudos in 1997," the minister said at a signing ceremony for a number of new road contracts.
He gave no further details of the railway investment.
The government would also send to Parliament a road development scheme to expand the country's motorway system by 50 percent by 1998, compared with 1995.
Cravinho said the new road plan would replace a 10-year highway improvement scheme introduced by the previous Social Democrat government which was only half completed.
Under the new plan, private sector construction companies would be allowed to act as operators of stretches of toll-paying motorway after building them, Cravinho said.
Up until now, the administering of motorways has been a monopoly of state construction company Brisa.
The signing covered contracts for the construction of some 83 km of motorway in the north and east of the country.
Cravinho said the cabinet would discuss the proposal to open the operation of motorways up to private capital during the first half of September.
